facts.text: Petition filed as Original Jurisdiction Petition No. 90 of 1956 under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 90 of 1956. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 12, 1961 by MUDHOLKAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Two unions of textile workers in Nagpur: Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh and Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh

anchor.surface_text: The facts which have led up to the petition are briefly as follows There are two unions of textile workers in Nagpur, one known as the Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh and the other as Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh.

facts.text: Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh is a branch of the Indian National Trade Union Congress

anchor.surface_text: The former is a branch of the Indian National Trade Union Congress. The Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh entered into an agreement with the management of the Empress Mills

facts.text: Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh entered into agreement with Empress Mills management regarding closure of Empress Mill No. 1 for rebuilding and employment of workers in third shift

anchor.surface_text: The Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh entered into an agreement with the management of the Empress Mills regarding the closure of Empress Mill No. 1 for rebuilding it and regarding the employment of workers who were employed therein in a third shift.

facts.text: Agreement opposed by Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh

anchor.surface_text: This agreement was opposed by the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh. On January 25, 1956, a group of workers belonging to the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh

facts.text: On January 25, 1956, group of workers from Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh went in procession to Gujars Wada, Mahal, Nagpur, office of Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh

anchor.surface_text: On January 25, 1956, a group of workers belonging to the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh went in a procession to Gujars Wada, Mahal, Nagpur, where the office of the Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh is located.

facts.text: Scuffle took place between members of the procession and workers of Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh

anchor.surface_text: 54 It is said that a scuffle took place there between some members of the procession and some workers belonging to Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh.

facts.text: Offence under s.452 read with s.147 IPC registered by police on January 27, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon an offence under s. 452 read with s. 147 of the Indian Penal Code was registered by the police on January 27, 1956.

facts.text: Large procession of Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh workers marched through Nagpur shouting provocative slogans according to District Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: A large procession companysisting of the workers of the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh was taken out. This procession marched through the city of Nagpur shouting slogans which, according to the District Magistrate, were provocative.

facts.text: Meeting held at Kasturchand Park where speakers instigated Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh workers to offer satyagraha in front of Empress Mill No.1 and procession to Rashtriya office

anchor.surface_text: On the same night a meeting was held at the Kasturchand Park in which it was alleged that the workers belonging to the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh were instigated by the speakers who addressed the meeting to offer satyagraha in front of the Empress Mill No. 1 and also to take out a procession to the office of the Rashtriya Mill Majdoor Sangh.

facts.text: On January 28, 1956, Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh workers assembled in large numbers in Mahal Chowk and Mahal road, blocking traffic, squatting on road

anchor.surface_text: On January 28,1956, the workers belonging to the Nagpur Mill Majdoor Sangh assembled in large numbers in Mahal Chowk and on Mahal road blocking the traffic on the road.

facts.text: District Magistrate passed order under s.144 CrPC at 4:00 a.m. on January 29, 1956, effective immediately for 15 days, prohibiting assembly of five or more persons in specified areas

anchor.surface_text: It is said that these persons were squatting on the road and as they refused to budge the District Magistrate passed an order at 4-00 a.m. on January 29, 1956, which came into force immediately and was to remain in force for a period of fifteen days prohibiting, among other things, the assembly of five or more persons in certain areas specified in the order.

facts.text: Petitioner held public meeting outside the area covered by the s.144 order, criticised District Magistrate, exhorted workers to contravene the order and take out processions

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner entertained the view that the order promulgated by the District Magistrate under s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was an encroachment on the fundamental rights... It is alleged that at that meeting he criticised the District Magistrate and exhorted the workers to companytravene his order and take out processions in the area companyered by the order.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested by Nagpur police for offences under ss.143 and 188 IPC read with s.117 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon he was arrested by the Nagpur police for having companymitted the offences already referred to and produced before a magistrate,

facts.text: Magistrate remanded petitioner to jail custody till February 15, 1956

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate remanded him to jail custody till February 15, 1956. The petitioners application for bail was rejected

facts.text: Petitioner's bail application rejected by magistrate as accusation related to non-bailable offence

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners application for bail was rejected on the ground that the accusation against him related to a Don-bailable offence.

facts.text: High Court at Nagpur rejected petitioner's bail application on February 22, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the petitioner moved the High Court at Nagpur for his release on bail but his application was rejected on February 22, 1956.

facts.text: High Court dismissed petitioner's petition under s.491 CrPC for habeas corpus on May 9, 1956

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then presented a petition before the High Court under s. 491 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for a writ of habeas companypus. That petition was dismissed by the High Court on May 9, 1956.

facts.text: High Court refused certificate under Art.132 as no substantial question of law or otherwise fit

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then moved the High Court for granting a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution. The High Court refused to grant the certificate number the ground that in its opinion the case did number involve any substantial question of law regarding the interpretation of the Constitution and was also number otherwise fit for grant of a certificate.

facts.text: Petition presented before Supreme Court on April 23, 1956

anchor.surface_text: On April 23, 1956, the petitioner presented the present petition before this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court admitted petition but rejected ex parte stay application

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner also sought an exparte order for the stay of the proceedings before the respondent No. 4 till the decision on the petition to this Court. This Court admitted the petition but rejected the application for stay.

facts.text: On May 28, 1956, Supreme Court ordered recording of entire prosecution evidence but stayed delivery of judgment pending petition

anchor.surface_text: On May 28,1956, this Court ordered that the entire prosecution evidence be recorded but the delivery of the judgment be stayed pending the decision of this petition.

facts.text: After proceedings stayed, petitioner released on bail by trying magistrate

anchor.surface_text: After the proceedings were stayed by this Court, the petitioner was released on bail by the trying magistrate.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the petition

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, dismiss this petition.
Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental rights.
1961. January 12. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR, J.-This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Shortly after this petition was made to this Court, the petitioner presented a special leave petition in which he seeks to challenge the judgment of the Nagpur High Court dated April 9, 1956, dismissing his writ petition to that High Court.

issues.text: Whether s.144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure confers very wide powers on the District Magistrate placing unreasonable restrictions on the rights under Art.19(1)(a) and (b)?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioner Mr. Mani has raised the following contentions That s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in so far as it relates to placing of restrictions on freedom of speech and freedom of assembly confers very wide powers on the District Magistrate and certain other magistrates and thus places unreasonable restrictions on the rights guaranteed under Art. 19 1 a and b of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the remedies under s.144 CrPC (modification/rescission) and revision to High Court under ss.435/439 CrPC provide illusory judicial review?

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate constitutes the whole legal machinery and the only check for control on his powers is by way of a petition to him to modify or rescind the order, that thus the District Magistrate becomes a judge in his own cause-presumably, what learned counsel means is a judge with regard to his own decision-and so the remedy afforded by the section is illusory. Further the remedy by way of a revision application before the High Court against the order of the District Magis- trate is also illusory and thus in effect there can be numberjudicial review of his order in the proper sense of that expression.

issues.text: Whether the test of likelihood or tendency under s.144 CrPC for determining criminality in advance is unreasonable?

anchor.surface_text: 3 Section 144 adopts likelihood or tendency as tests for judging criminality the test of determining the criminality in advance is unreasonable.

issues.text: Whether s.144 CrPC substitutes suppression of lawful activity for the duty of public authorities to maintain order?

anchor.surface_text: Section 144 substitutes suppression of lawful activity or right for the duty of public authorities to maintain order.

issues.text: Whether the specific order passed by the District Magistrate under s.144 CrPC places restrictions beyond the scope of Art.19(2) and (3) and is unconstitutional?

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is number ultra vires the Constitution, the order passed by the District Magistrate in this case places restrictions which go far beyond the scope of clauses 2 and 3 of Art. 19 and thus that order is unconstitutional.

issues.text: Whether the order under s.144 is vague, particularly regarding 'provocative slogans', imposing unreasonable restrictions?

anchor.surface_text: The third and last ground on which Mr. Mani challenged the constitutionality of the order was that while the order prohibits the shouting of provocative slogans in public places etc., it does number give any definition of what was meant by the expression provocative slogans . Therefore, according to Mr. Mani, this order is vague and must be deemed to be placing unreasonable restrictions on the rights of free speech of citizens.

arguments.claim: s.144 CrPC confers very wide powers on District Magistrate placing unreasonable restrictions on Art.19(1)(a) and (b)

Further the remedy by way of a revision application before the High Court against the order of the District Magis- trate is also illusory and thus in effect there can be number judicial review of his order in the proper sense of that expression.

Therefore, according to Mr. Mani, this order is vague and must be deemed to be placing unreasonable restrictions on the rights of free speech of citizens.

arguments.claim: s.144 confers powers on magistrates acting judicially with safeguards; reasonable under Art.19

anchor.surface_text: This being a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution, the petitioner must restrict himself to those grounds which fall within cl.  1  thereof. We think it desirable to reproduce the whole of s. 144. In cases where, in the opinion of a District Magistrate...

arguments.claim: s.144 objects fall within 'public order' not wider 'public interest'; no need for special law

anchor.surface_text: Firstly, according to learned companynsel restrictions on the rights guaranteed by cls.  2  and  3  of Art. 19 of the Constitution can be placed in the interest of id public order and number in the interest of the general public , which expression, according to him is wider in its ambit than public order...

arguments.claim: Magistrate must enquire/set out material facts; power not arbitrary

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, according to learned companynsel sub-s.  1  of a. 144 does number require the magistrate to make an enquiry as to the circumstances which necessitate the making of an order thereunder... Clearly, therefore, the section does number companyfer an arbitrary power on the magistrate...

arguments.claim: Power under s.144 conditioned by emergency factors; not unlimited

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure companyfers very wide powers upon certain magistrates... These factors companydition the exercise of the power and it would companysequently be wrong to regard that power as being unlimited or untrammelled.

arguments.claim: s.144 restrictions reasonable under Art.19(2)(3) as emergency measure

anchor.surface_text: The rights guaranteed by sub-cl.  a  are number absolute rights but are subject to limitations specified in cl.  2  of Art. 19... The Code of Criminal Procedure was an existing law... what we have to ascertain is whether the companyferral thereunder of a power on a magistrate to place restrictions... is reasonable.

arguments.claim: Formation of opinion on emergency by magistrate reasonable; not subjective

anchor.surface_text: It must be borne in mind that the provisions of s. 144 are attracted only in an emergency... The provisions of the section therefore which companymit the power in this regard to a magistrate... cannot be regarded as unreasonable.

arguments.claim: Remedies under s.144 real: hearing, revision to High Court effective

anchor.surface_text: Again, though numberappeal has been provided... the High Court has power under s. 435 read with s. 439... The powers of the High Court... wide enough to enable it to quash an order...

arguments.claim: Clear and present danger test inapplicable; anticipatory action allowed under Art.19

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the test of determining criminality in advance is unreasonable, is apparently founded upon the doctrine adumbrated in Schenecks case 2  that previous restraints... It seems to us, however, that the American doctrine cannot be imported under our Constitution...

arguments.claim: Petition dismissed as s.144 and order constitutional

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

holdings.text: Section 144 CrPC does not confer arbitrary or unreasonable powers on magistrates and the restrictions it imposes are reasonable under Articles 19(2) and 19(3).

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, therefore, the section does not confer an arbitrary power on the magistrate in the matter of making an order. It is contended that s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure confers very wide powers upon certain magistrates and that in exercise of those powers the magistrates can place very severe restrictions upon the rights of citizens to freedom of speech and expression and to assemble peaceably and without arms.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate must state material facts, act in emergency, power conditioned by specific factors like preventing obstruction or danger to public tranquility; existing law at Constitution commencement, subject to reasonableness test.

holdings.text: Remedies under s.144(4),(5) CrPC and revision to High Court under ss.435,439 CrPC provide real judicial review, not illusory.

anchor.surface_text: Again, though no appeal has been provided in the Code against the Magistrates order under s. 144, the High Court has power under s. 435 read with s. 439 of the Code to entertain an application for the revision of such an order,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.144(4),(5) require hearing applicant and recording reasons; High Court revision powers wide to quash unsupported orders, as in P.T. Chandra case; prosecution allows challenge to order validity.

holdings.text: Likelihood or tendency test under s.144 for anticipatory restrictions is reasonable; clear and present danger test inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that the test of determining criminality in advance is unreasonable, is apparently founded upon the doctrine adumbrated in Schencks case that previous restraints on the exercise of fundamental rights are permissible only if there be a clear and present danger.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.19(2),(3) permit anticipatory restrictions for public order; US doctrine not importable as Indian Constitution expressly allows reasonable restrictions in interest of public order without absolute rights.

holdings.text: s.144 does not substitute suppression of lawful activity for duty to maintain order; anticipatory action discharges duty.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that since the duty to maintain law and order is cast upon the Magistrate, he must perform that duty and not shirk it by prohibiting or restricting the normal activities of the citizen.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In emergency where danger apprehended, anticipatory action is mode of discharging duty to maintain public order.

holdings.text: Specific order under s.144 by District Magistrate not unconstitutional as beyond Art.19(2),(3).

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is not unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order directed to public generally practical as difficult to distinguish union members; exemptions via s.144(4); not vague in context.

holdings.text: Order prohibiting 'provocative slogans' not vague or unreasonable restriction on free speech.

anchor.surface_text: The third and last ground on which Mr. Mani challenged the constitutionality of the order was that while the order prohibits the shouting of provocative slogans in public places etc., it does not give any definition of what was meant by the expression provocative slogans .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Expression understood in context of industrial dispute and prior provocative events; not vague.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All challenges to s.144 and order rejected; no violation of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is number unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights. We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

anchor.surface_text: Clearly, therefore, the section does not confer an arbitrary power on the magistrate in the matter of making an order. It is contended that s. 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure confers very wide powers upon certain magistrates and that in exercise of those powers the magistrates can place very severe restrictions upon the rights of citizens to freedom of speech and expression and to assemble peaceably and without arms.

We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is number unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights. We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

anchor.surface_text: Again, though no appeal has been provided in the Code against the Magistrates order under s. 144, the High Court has power under s. 435 read with s. 439 of the Code to entertain an application for the revision of such an order,

We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is number unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights. We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

The argument that the test of determining criminality in advance is unreasonable, is apparently founded upon the doctrine adumbrated in Schencks case that previous restraints on the exercise of fundamental rights are permissible only if there be a clear and present danger.

We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is number unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights. We, therefore, dismiss this petition.

It is no doubt true that since the duty to maintain law and order is cast upon the Magistrate, he must perform that duty and not shirk it by prohibiting or restricting the normal activities of the citizen.

We have, therefore, reached the conclusion that the order of the District Magistrate is number unconstitutional either because s. 144 is itself violative of fundamental rights recognised in Art. 19 or on the ground that it is vague and places unreasonable restrictions on those fundamental rights. We, therefore, dismiss this petition.
